docs.snippet: Alex Rodriguez joined the Yankees for the first time since the disappointing end to last year’s playoffs when he was benched. He was in uniform in the clubhouse before Monday’s opening game of the season, and spoke briefly with repor...
docs.lead_paragraph:
Alex Rodriguez joined the Yankees for the first time since the disappointing end to last year’s playoffs when he was benched. He was in uniform in the clubhouse before Monday’s opening game of the season, and spoke briefly with reporters.
 
He was not introduced before the game but was on the bench in uniform when the game began.
docs.abstract: New York Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez attracts significant attention as spectator during team's season opener against Boston Red Sox, despite fact that he is far from ready to return to lineup; other baseball news noted. Photo (M)1

headline.main: Plenty of Focus On Rodriguez The Spectator

docs.snippet: Mariano Rivera was out shagging fly balls during batting practice Monday but did not run as hard as he did last May, when he tore ligaments in his right knee while doing the same thing in Kansas City and missed the rest of the season. Rivera said ...
docs.lead_paragraph:
Mariano Rivera was out shagging fly balls during batting practice Monday but did not run as hard as he did last May, when he tore ligaments in his right knee while doing the same thing in Kansas City and missed the rest of the season. Rivera said he would continue to shag fly balls and expected to get up to full speed before long.
 
“I wouldn’t change anything I do,” he said.
docs.abstract: New York Yankees closer Mariano Rivera shags fly balls during batting practice and hopes to be part of team's rotation soon. (S)

headline.main: Rivera Is Back . . . in the Outfield

headline.main: Leading Off: The Dodgers' Hollywood Opening

docs.snippet:
Thriftland U.S.A., a large second-hand store in the South Bronx, seems an unlikely place to claim a piece of New York Yankees history. 
   
“I hate the Yankees — every time there’s a home game, it totally messes up the...
docs.lead_paragraph:
Thriftland U.S.A., a large second-hand store in the South Bronx, seems an unlikely place to claim a piece of New York Yankees history. 
 
“I hate the Yankees — every time there’s a home game, it totally messes up the parking in this neighborhood,” said Mark Kassof, an owner of Thriftland, at River Avenue and 153rd Street, just south of Yankee Stadium.
docs.abstract: City Room blog; many New York Yankee fans attending 2013 opening day recall Freddy Schuman, fan who became something of a team mascot, roaming stadium banging on an old frying pan with a spoon to rouse fans and cheer on players; Freddy the Fan, as he was known, began the tradition in 1988 and it lasted until his death in 2010 at age 85. Photos (M)

headline.main: Where a Famed Yankee Fan Would Stock Up on Gear

docs.snippet: Despite low expectations and an opening day opponent with no marquee names, the Mets said they sold out Citi Field on Monday. The team said that 41,053 tickets were purchased and that an additional 1,000 tickets were given to first responders and ...
docs.lead_paragraph:
Despite low expectations and an opening day opponent with no marquee names, the Mets said they sold out Citi Field on Monday. The team said that 41,053 tickets were purchased and that an additional 1,000 tickets were given to first responders and to victims of Hurricane Sandy .
 
From the press box, though, the stadium did not look full. There were large pockets of empty seats, including entire rows with no fans in the right-field corner and upper deck. The Mets also had plenty of tickets for sale on their Web site two hours before the game. Scalpers outside the stadium were selling seats for below face value, and some fans were giving away tickets in the plaza in front of the stadium.
docs.abstract: New York Mets claim to sell out Citi Field for season opener, despite low expectations, but large number of seats appear empty nonetheless. (M)

docs.snippet: Teams increasingly want their radio analysts fluent in the language of WAR — that’s wins above replacement — and other advanced statistics, known as sabermetrics....
docs.lead_paragraph: Teams increasingly want their radio analysts fluent in the language of WAR — that’s wins above replacement — and other advanced statistics, known as sabermetrics.
docs.abstract: Radio broadcasts of baseball games, one-sided conversations that create a cozy intimacy between fans and announcers, are colliding with cold calculations known as sabermetrics; as statistical analysis becomes part of the fabric of the game and an object of growing fascination to fans, teams increasingly want their radio announcers fluent in advanced statistics, known as sabermetrics, rather than homespun lore.

headline.seo: Baseball Broadcasts Introduce Advanced Statistics, but With Caution
headline.main: Era of Modern Baseball Stats Brings WAR to Booth
headline.print_headline: Modern Stats Bring WAR to Broadcast Booth (B.A.B.I.P., Too)

byline.contributor: David Waldstein and Andrew Keh contributed reporting.
